title: 103_s47
content: Special habeas corpus procedures in capital cases are outlined in a new chapter inserted into Title 28 of the United States Code. Special habeas corpus procedures in capital cases are outlined in a new chapter inserted into Title 28 of the United States Code. This chapter applies to cases under section 2254 brought by prisoners in State custody subject to a capital sentence, with specific requirements for appointment of counsel. This chapter applies to State post-conviction proceedings for indigent prisoners with upheld capital convictions. It requires the appointment of competent counsel and sets standards for competency. The mechanism must offer counsel to all State prisoners under a capital sentence and provide for court appointment upon a finding of indigence or inability to decide. The chapter applies to State post-conviction proceedings for indigent prisoners with upheld capital convictions. It mandates the appointment of competent counsel and sets competency standards. Counsel must be offered to all State prisoners under a capital sentence, appointed upon a finding of indigence or inability to decide. Counsel appointed for a State prisoner under a capital sentence cannot have previously represented the prisoner at trial or on direct appeal unless requested. Ineffectiveness or incompetence of counsel during post-conviction proceedings in a capital case is not grounds for relief. Different counsel can be appointed at any phase of post-conviction proceedings. Mandatory stay of execution is also addressed with limits on stays. The chapter mandates the appointment of competent counsel for indigent prisoners with upheld capital convictions. Different counsel can be appointed at any phase of post-conviction proceedings. A stay of execution can be granted upon application to the appropriate court, subject to certain conditions. The chapter mandates competent counsel for indigent prisoners with upheld capital convictions. A stay of execution or relief in a capital case can only be granted under specific conditions, including the denial of a certiorari petition or a waiver of habeas corpus review by the prisoner. Federal court can grant a stay of execution or relief in a capital case under specific conditions, including presenting a new claim not previously raised, failure to raise the claim due to certain reasons, and if the facts could undermine the jury's determination of guilt. The filing of a habeas corpus petition for relief in a capital case must be done within 180 days after a state court order is issued. Time requirements can be tolled in certain circumstances, such as when a petition for certiorari is filed in the Supreme Court or during post-conviction review in a state court. The time requirement for filing a habeas corpus petition in a capital case can be extended under certain circumstances. The time can be tolled during post-conviction review in a state court if all State filing rules are met. Tolling does not occur during a petition for certiorari before the Supreme Court. Sec. 2259 outlines the procedures for evidentiary hearings and Federal review in habeas corpus cases for State prisoners under a capital sentence. The district court must assess the sufficiency of the evidentiary record based on claims presented in State courts, unless certain exceptions apply. The district court must conduct any necessary evidentiary hearings to complete the record for habeas corpus review. Upon the development of a complete evidentiary record, the court will rule on the merits of the claims. The requirement of a certificate of probable cause for appeal does not apply to habeas corpus cases under this chapter, except for second or successive petitions.
